keyFactors.title: Offensive Efficiency Edge (+3.6 Rating)
keyFactors.description: Illinois State Offensive Rating: 114.2 (42nd nationally) vs. Ohio 110.6 (106th) = +3.6 edge. More efficient scoring attack with better shot selection.

keyFactors.title: Strength of Schedule Advantage
keyFactors.description: Illinois State: -0.57 SOS vs. Ohio: -4.37 SOS = played better competition. MVC (Missouri Valley Conference) significantly stronger than MAC (Mid-American Conference).

keyFactors.title: Historical Dominance
keyFactors.description: Previous meeting (Nov 12, 2024): Illinois State won 85-75 (10-point margin). Familiarity with opponent and proven ability to win at Ohio.

keyFactors.title: Ohio's Defensive Weakness
keyFactors.description: Ohio ranked 304th nationally in points allowed (76.5 PPG in 2024-25). Defensive Rating: 106.0 (216th) vs. Illinois State 108.2 (273rd). Both teams weak defensively but Ohio worse.

keyFactors.title: Net Efficiency Favors Illinois State
keyFactors.description: Net efficiency: +1.4 favoring Illinois State. Estimated fair line: Pick'em or Illinois State -0.5. Getting +1.5 represented modest value.

riskFactors: Ohio home court advantage worth ~2-3 points
Ohio picked 1st in MAC preseason poll (expectations high)
Illinois State season opener (potential rust/chemistry issues)
Edge only +4-7% (thin margin for 1.5 unit stake)

quarterBreakdown.description: Tied 31-31 at halftime. Competitive first half with neither team establishing control. Both teams shot well but turnovers kept score close.
Illinois State took first lead at 50-49 with 11:03 remaining. Showed offensive efficiency edge with better shot selection and ball movement.
Ohio responded with crucial 9-2 run to take 58-52 lead. Never trailed again. Ohio's home court and defensive adjustments shifted momentum permanently.
Illinois State cut deficit to 64-61 with 2:44 left (Chase Walker 3-pointer). Showed fight but couldn't complete comeback. Mason Klabo's desperation 3 with 2 seconds made final 72-68.

gameResults.whenMissed: Ohio's 9-2 run after Illinois State took 50-49 lead was turning point. Never recovered. Lost by 4 points, missing +1.5 spread by 2.5 points.
gameResults.gamePace: 140 total points (well under 160.5 O/U). Competitive pace with both teams executing offensively but defensive stands in crucial moments.
gameResults.foulTrouble: No significant foul trouble for either team. Ohio's 4 turnovers vs. Illinois State's 9 provided extra possessions that proved decisive.

whatWentWrong.title: Rebounding Deficit Catastrophic (PRIMARY FACTOR)
whatWentWrong.description: Outrebounded 29-17 (12-rebound gap). Extra possessions for Ohio created scoring opportunities that Illinois State couldn't match. Second-chance points killed comeback attempts.

whatWentWrong.title: 2nd Half Execution Failed
whatWentWrong.description: Ohio outscored ISU 41-37 after tied halftime. Ohio's 9-2 run after ISU took lead (50-49) shifted momentum permanently. Couldn't maintain offensive efficiency in crucial stretch.

whatWentWrong.title: Turnover Advantage Squandered
whatWentWrong.description: Ohio only 4 TOs vs. ISU's 9, but couldn't capitalize. Extra possessions didn't translate to points. Poor shot selection on bonus possessions.

whatWentWrong.title: Home Court Advantage Realized
whatWentWrong.description: Ohio's home court at Convocation Center worth ~2-3 points. Crowd energy during 9-2 run provided momentum. Fair line (Ohio -0.5 to ISU +0.5) meant getting +1.5 wasn't enough cushion.

statisticalContext.vsRecentForm: Previous meeting: Lost by 4 (was up 10 points last year)
statisticalContext.percentileRanking: Competitive game but fell short in execution

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: Close game that came down to execution. The +1.5 represented slight value given Illinois State's offensive efficiency advantage (+3.6 rating) and historical dominance (10-point win previous year). However, rebounding deficit (12-rebound gap) and Ohio's timely 9-2 run were difference-makers. Not analytical failure - fair line would have been Ohio -0.5 to Illinois State +0.5, so getting +1.5 provided thin cushion that wasn't enough.

closingLineValue.verdict: Minimal CLV (+5 cents). Line moved slightly toward Illinois State as market recognized offensive efficiency edge. However, edge was thin (4-7%) and didn't justify 1.5 unit stake in retrospect.

keyTakeaways: Rebounding differentials in college basketball are highly predictive - 12-rebound gap was catastrophic
Home court advantage in college basketball worth 2-3 points - must factor into handicap
Thin edges (4-7%) should warrant smaller stakes (0.5-1.0u, not 1.5u)
Turnover advantages don't always translate to wins if shot selection poor
Previous season results provide context but roster changes matter significantly
Ohio's 9-2 run after ISU took lead was pivotal momentum shift - execution matters in close games
Stake sizing error: 1.5 units too aggressive for 4-7% edge
verdict: Slight analytical edge existed (offensive efficiency +3.6, historical dominance) but stake sizing was inappropriate. 1.5 units on a 4-7% edge is too aggressive. Should have been 0.5-1.0 unit max. Close game came down to rebounding and key run - not a process failure, but stake sizing needs improvement for thin-edge spots.
